identity.name: Karol Buczek
identity.headline: Web Systems Engineer • WordPress & MarTech • Internal Tools & Automation
summary: Karol is a systems-oriented web engineer who builds end-to-end solutions: custom WordPress engineering, backend automations, data flows, and internal tools.
He’s not just a ‘WordPress dev’ or a ‘marketing guy who codes’—he specializes in the intersection of WordPress, MarTech, backend scripting, and product-like internal tools.
He’s comfortable leveraging AI tools (like Cursor) as an accelerator, but still thinks in terms of architecture, maintainability, and real-world business outcomes.

careerGoals.primaryIntent2025_2026: Secure a well-paying full-time or strong contract role while continuing to build his own products and client work on the side.
careerGoals.longTerm: Return to primarily self-employment with a stronger financial cushion, higher day rate, and a deeper portfolio of products/tools.

jobSearchStrategyNotes: Karol wants a list of job titles he can search for; tailoring should happen per-job, not in the generic brief.
He is fine working at mid-sized companies, strongly prefers not to be a faceless contributor at massive bureaucratic orgs, unless the compensation is clearly worth it.
Remote is ideal; hybrid or in-office is negotiable if the role is strong enough.

Lead ingestion scripts from aggregators, sales & marketing data pipelines, and dashboard work for call center and channel ROI KPIs.

Designed and implemented internal dashboards to track salespeople efficiency and multi-channel opportunity, spend, and ROI.

Has several product ideas (workout tracker, AI-assisted shopping/meal planning app) intended as future, real-world portfolio projects.

likes: Architecting systems and workflows; thinking about features and future optimizations.
Solving real problems with code, especially when AI tools can speed up implementation.
Backend logic, automation, and integrations (PHP/SQL/cron/Zapier/API scripts).
UX and flow design at a conceptual level—making interfaces and funnels function better and convert better.

dislikes: Being pigeonholed as a marketing copywriter or basic content marketer.

Cheap, underpriced work or ‘fast and cheap’ clients who don’t value quality.

aiUsage: Karol uses AI (including Cursor) as a code accelerator and collaborator rather than as a replacement for understanding.
He does not want to be branded as a ‘vibe coder’; he has years of pre-AI coding experience and wants that credibility preserved.
In instructions, avoid overselling the ‘AI engineer’ angle; it’s fine to mention he uses AI effectively but it should not be the core brand.

highPriorityCaseStudies.title: Enterprise Core Web Vitals Optimization via Custom Gutenberg Block
keyPoints: Large corporate WP site with custom theme, tested via Lighthouse with controlled variables (same images, same theme, etc.).
Problem: slow LCP due to inefficient hero/container markup and image delivery.
Solution: built a VIP-compliant custom top-funnel block in a plugin that optimized markup, loading strategy, and layout.
Results (averaged): LCP improved from approx. 5.5s to 3.2s; Lighthouse performance from ~70 to ~83; slight improvement in Speed Index; other metrics stable.
Emphasize safe, non-invasive architecture: plugin-based, minimal risk to existing theme, designed for enterprise safety.

highPriorityCaseStudies.title: UTM Persistence & First/Last Touch Attribution Plugin
keyPoints: Stores UTM parameters across sessions via cookies/localStorage.
Injects UTM + attribution data into Gravity Forms submissions.
Enables first-touch and last-touch tracking, especially helpful for blending direct mail with digital funnels.
Concrete MarTech example: solves attribution gaps and supports better spend decisions.

highPriorityCaseStudies.title: Custom GTM Event Button Block for Marketers
keyPoints: Gutenberg block that emits structured events into the GTM dataLayer.
Configurable fields (text inputs or dropdowns) for eventType/eventName so marketers can tag interaction semantics without developer intervention.
Reduces friction, speeds up tracking implementations, and standardizes event logic at scale.

highPriorityCaseStudies.title: Secure File Sharing Portal on AWS (Amplify, Cognito, S3, RDS, Lambda)
keyPoints: Built for a client requiring secure, compliant document workflows.
Uses Cognito for auth, S3 with signed URLs & folder isolation, RDS for metadata, and Lambda to create per-user folder structures on account creation.
Roles: user, admin, and a dev/super-admin role for debugging & support.
Includes delete protection (two-step delete with retention window) and audit logging, plus a debug dashboard for tracing errors.
Shows full-stack, cloud, and product-level thinking.

highPriorityCaseStudies.title: Backend Workflow Automations & Data Pipelines
keyPoints: PHP + SQL scripts on VPS with cron, moving leads and customer data through workflows based on funnel stage and status.
Integrations with Mailchimp, Birdeye, Five9, CRMs, Hover, HatchApp, lead aggregators, and other marketing/sales tools.
Large table reads/writes with custom logic for notifications (email & SMS), app state transitions, and follow-up sequences.
Custom logging/error handling frameworks to support maintainability and troubleshooting.

highPriorityCaseStudies.title: Modular Zapier Architecture with SubZaps
keyPoints: Took large, unmaintainable Zaps (70+ steps) and refactored them into modular SubZap systems.
Resulted in ~20–22-step flows that are easier to follow, extend, and debug.
Reduced edge-case handling time and made it easier to roll out features across multiple automations.
Demonstrates systems thinking, operational empathy, and process engineering.

futurePersonalProducts.title: Smart AI Shopping & Pantry Planner
futurePersonalProducts.intent: A personal-product idea to reduce waste and decision friction around food.
notes: Core job: help Karol use what he has, avoid waste, and plan meals based on real pantry contents.
MVP features: pantry inventory tracking, AI suggestions based on ‘what you have’, recipe recommendations when 2/3 ingredients exist, store/section/priority-organized lists, natural language inputs.
Future features: photo-based pantry/fridge scanning, receipt parsing, integration with recipe APIs (if free/accessible).

toneAndFraming: Do NOT frame Karol primarily as a marketing director or generic marketer; he is a systems-oriented engineer who also understands marketing and data.
Do NOT lean too heavily into company names (like UWD, PPW, Mineralife, etc.) unless needed for clarity—focus on the work and outcomes.
Do NOT present him as a junior or mid-level developer; his portfolio is senior-level in complexity and autonomy.
Avoid ‘AI vibe coder’ language; it’s fine to say he uses AI tools effectively, but his credibility comes from experience + architecture, not AI alone.
When writing resumes, cover letters, and portfolio copy, emphasize problem-solving, architecture, measurable outcomes, and cross-functional collaboration.
whenHelpingWithJobApplications: Always tailor outputs to specific job descriptions Karol provides (e.g., WordPress Engineer vs MarTech Engineer vs Product/Integrations Engineer).
Prefer practical, portfolio-oriented language over buzzwords. Reference specific plugins, blocks, scripts, or systems when relevant to the job.
Highlight measurable results when available (e.g., LCP improvements, performance score lifts, reduced steps in Zapier, etc.).
Emphasize that Karol is comfortable collaborating with stakeholders and other disciplines (designers, marketers, product managers) while owning the technical implementation.
When writing outreach messages (LinkedIn DMs, emails), keep them concise, credible, and problem-focused—avoid generic ‘I’m passionate about…’ fluff.
salaryAndExpectations: For full-time roles, anchor comp expectations between $110k–$150k, noting that $140k+ is the ideal zone given his experience.
For contract or part-time roles, anchor around $65–$75/hour with justification around seniority and hybrid skill set.
Karol is open to working hard (up to ~60 hrs/week across job + clients) in the short term to hit his financial stabilization and growth goals.
